questions.text: A 32 year old male arrives at the emergency department with severe facial burns after being involved in a car accident. The patient’s facial burns are extensive, covering the entire face and neck region, and have caused significant swelling. He is conscious and in pain, but his airway is patent. Which method of dressing should be chosen for this patient's facial burns, and why?

options.label: A
options.text: Exposure Method – To allow continuous monitoring of the facial burns and prevent airway compromise.

options.label: B
options.text: Closed Method – To reduce the risk of infection by providing a protective barrier over the burned area.

options.label: C
options.text: Exposure Method – To facilitate a moist environment that promotes healing in the facial area.

options.label: D
options.text: Closed Method – To minimize fluid loss from the burned area and aid in preventing dehydration.

questions.correct_answer: A. Exposure Method – To allow continuous monitoring of the facial burns and prevent airway compromise.
questions.explanation:
Exposure method

Closed method
  • No dressing is done.
  • Antimicrobials are given 2-3 times/day.
  • They are used for burns involving the face & the head.
  • Disadvantages:
    • Increased pain & heat loss.
    • Increased risk of cross-contamination.
  • Occlusive dressing is applied over the antimicrobial agent.
  • The dressing is changed twice daily.
  • Advantages:
    • Decreased pain & heat loss.
    • Decreased risk of cross-contamination.
  • Disadvantages:
    • Increased risk of bacterial growth if the dressing is not changed twice daily.

options.label: D

questions.correct_answer: C. Refer to a burn center for specialized treatment
questions.explanation:
Indications of referral to burns center

Suspected airway injury
  • Burns on face/neck, hoarseness, stridor, singed facial/nasal hair

Burns needing fluid resuscitation
  • >15% TBSA in adults
  • >10% in children/elderly

Burns requiring surgery
  • Deep partial-thickness (deep dermis damage)
  • Full-thickness (entire dermis destroyed)
  • Circumferential full-thickness (restricted movement)

Significant burns
  • Burns on hands, face, feet and perineum

Psychiatric/social concerns
  • Mental health issues, substance abuse and unstable living conditions

Suspected non-accidental injury
  • Delayed presentation, inconsistent history and unexplained injuries

Extremes of age
  • Infants, elderly with thinner skin and higher risk of complications

Burns with serious sequelae
  • High-tension electrical burns, hydrofluoric acid burns, etc.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the emergency department with complaints of extensive burns on his back, chest, and legs. On examination, the affected areas are dry, leathery, and charred black with no blister formation.What is the most likely type of burn?

Match the type of burn with its corresponding characteristic: Type of Burn Characteristics 1. First-degree burn A. Blistering, partial-thickness damage 2. Second-degree burn B. Charring, full-thickness skin damage 3. Third-degree burn C. Redness, Epidermal burn 4. Fourth-degree burn D. Involvement of muscles and bones
questions.explanation:
Type of Burn

Characteristics

First-degree burn

  • Redness, Epidermal burn
  • Involves only epidermis
  • Painful and erythematous with no blisters.
  • Healing time: 5-10 days

Second-degree burn

  • Blistering, partial-thickness skin damage
  • Superficial partial thickness burn- Epidermis + Papillary dermis
  • Deep partial thickness burn- Epidermis + reticular dermis
  • Healing time: 2-3 weeks

Third-degree burn

  • Charring, full-thickness skin damage
  • Involvement of epidermis + dermis + subcutaneous fat

Fourth-degree burn

  • Involvement of skin and underlying muscles and bones

questions.text: In burn injuries, which zone is characterized by necrotic tissue and irreversible cell damage at the time of injury?

A 55-year-old male with a history of a recent traumatic brain injury presents with sudden epigastric pain, vomiting of blood, and black stools. He is diagnosed with a Cushing ulcer. Despite initial management with IV fluids and proton pump inhibitors (PPIs), the patient continues to bleed. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.label: A
options.text: Increase the dose of IV PPIs and observe for improvement.

options.label: B
options.text: Perform an urgent endoscopy to control the bleeding.

options.label: C
options.text: Schedule the patient for a planned surgical vagotomy and pyloroplasty.

options.label: D
options.text: Refer the patient for immediate angiography with embolization.

questions.correct_answer: B. Perform an urgent endoscopy to control the bleeding.
questions.explanation:
Cushing Ulcer

Pathophysiology
  • Cushing's ulcer is a gastro-duodenal ulcer caused by increased intracranial pressure (ICP), commonly due to brain tumors, head injuries or other intracranial conditions.
  • Vagal Stimulation: Overstimulation of the vagus nerve due to elevated ICP leads to increased gastric acid secretion.
  • Sympathetic Paralysis: Disruption in sympathetic pathways may exacerbate the imbalance in gastric secretions, contributing to ulcer formation.

Clinical Presentation
  • Epigastric pain
  • Nausea and vomiting.
  • Gastrointestinal bleeding, presenting as hematemesis (vomiting blood) or melena (black stools).
  • Potential complications include ulcer perforation and peritonitis, which are life-threatening if untreated.

Initial Management
  • Prophylaxis may fail (Option A).
  • Resuscitation: Begins with crystalloids and early use of balanced blood products.
  • Coagulopathy Correction: FFP or platelet transfusions are needed for coagulopathy or antiplatelet drug use.
  • Nasogastric Tube: Key for lavage and decompression in hemorrhagic stress gastritis.
  • Antisecretory Agents: IV PPIs are preferred over H2 antagonists for bleeding control.
  • Endoscopy: First-line for GI bleeding, effective despite high rebleed risk. (Option B)
  • Angiography: For failed endoscopy, involves embolization or vasopressin infusion. (Option D)

Surgical Indications
  • For unresponsive, recurrent bleeding or perforations.

Surgical Approach
  • A staged approach starting with bleeding control is safer.
  • Initial Surgery: Long midline incision for exploration; anterior gastrotomy to oversew bleeding sites.
  • Stable Patients: Vagotomy and pyloroplasty after bleeding control; abdominal closure.(Option C)
  • Unstable Patients: Leave the abdomen open for resuscitation; second surgery for vagotomy and pyloroplasty when stable.
  • Rare Procedures: Due to the high risks, gastric resection, subtotal or total gastrectomy, and gastric devascularization are rarely performed.

questions.text: Which among the following statements about the body responses to severe burns are true? A) Hypermetabolism after a burn increases oxygen consumption and leads to muscle wasting. B) The zone of coagulation is a reversible area of tissue damage in burns. C) Cardiopulmonary effects in severe burns can result in reduced cardiac output. D) Immune suppression following a burn increases the risk of infection. E) Inflammation and edema in burn injuries cause increased vascular permeability and fluid loss.
questions.explanation:
PATHOPHYSIOLOGY OF BURNS

Local responses:

Skin Damage
  • Burns cause cell membrane disruption and necrosis due to rapid temperature changes.
  • The depth of injury depends on temperature, exposure duration, and thermal conductivity (e.g., oil burns are deeper than water burns).

Jackson Levels
  • Zone of Coagulation: Irreversible tissue damage with cell destruction. (Statement B)
  • Zone of Stasis: Moderate damage with reduced perfusion; survival depends on timely intervention.
  • Zone of Hyperemia: Vasodilation around the wound; generally remains viable and aids healing.

Systemic Responses:

Inflammation & Edema
  • Burns trigger widespread inflammation, increasing vascular permeability, leading to fluid loss, edema, and decreased plasma volume. (Statement E)

Cardiopulmonary Effects
  • Microvascular changes reduce cardiac output, potentially leading to ventricular dysfunction despite fluid resuscitation. (Statement C)

Renal System
  • Decreased blood volume affects renal blood flow, risking acute tubular necrosis if not managed promptly.

Immune Suppression
  • Burns impair immune function, increasing infection risk due to compromised neutrophils, macrophages, and T lymphocytes. (Statement D)

Hypermetabolism
  • Burns induce a hypermetabolic state, leading to increased oxygen consumption, protein/fat breakdown, and muscle wasting.
  • The liver plays a key role in gluconeogenesis and fatty acid processing. (Statement A)

Ebb and Flow Phases
  • Post-injury, the body undergoes an initial low metabolic rate (ebb phase) followed by a hypermetabolic state (flow phase).

Complications:
  • Infection: Early excision and grafting of burns are crucial to prevent infections.
  • Organ Failure: Severe burns can lead to multiple organ failure due to a systemic inflammatory response.
